SEARCH
Module melange.common
Package gbw.melange.common.mesh.formatting.slicing

Interface IFloatSlice

All Superinterfaces:
Iterable<Float>
All Known Subinterfaces:
ISliceVec2, ISliceVec3, ISliceVec4
public interface IFloatSlice extends Iterable<Float>
Represents a slice of a float array for efficient, non-boxing access to a range of floats. This class is designed for performance-sensitive applications where direct access to the underlying array's elements is required without the overhead of boxing.
This is but the parent interface for many, vastly more usefull representations such as ISliceVec2, ISliceVec3, and ISliceVec4 which imitates the behaviour of a vector.
Note: The implementations does not support spliterator operations. Attempting to call spliterator() will result in a RuntimeException.
Author:
GustavBW

    • entryWidth

    • indexFirstComp

      int indexFirstComp()
      When the series of vector representations was retrieved from the buffer, that this is a part of, what is the index of the first component of this.

    • get

      float get(int index)
      Get the value at the index of the slice. Will throw an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException if you try and access indexes not within this specific slice.
      Returns:
      float

    • set

      void set(int index, float value)
      Set the value at some index in the source through this slice.
      Parameters:
      index - of this slice
      value - to set

    • forEachFloat

      void forEachFloat(IFloatSlice.FloatConsumer func)
      Iterate over each element in the slice using a method reference / lambda. Do be aware of the initialization cost of lambdas, so if used in a hot path, allocate the lambda outside of it or implement a method with signature: 
           <any> void methodName(float variableName) {...}
      And reference it from your code using fx. this::methodName if defined within the class where you're calling forEachFloat(FloatConsumer)
      Parameters:
      func - What to do with each float

    • copy

      IFloatSlice copy()

    • forEach

      void forEach(Consumer<? super Float> action)
      Don't use this, as this is the generic version and will cause boxing, but is required by the Iterable interface. Instead, use forEachFloat(FloatConsumer). You can help Java sort out its issues by declaring a lambda as of type FloatConsumer, or casting any method reference or lambda.
      Specified by:
      forEach in interface Iterable<Float>

    • spliterator

      Spliterator<Float> spliterator()
      Absolutely not supported. Will throw an exception if invoked. This also rules out processing a single slice using parallel streams.
      Specified by:
      spliterator in interface Iterable<Float>
      Returns:
      nothing
